questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer must configure new interfaces on a set of devices and is planning to use an Ansible playbook for the task. All devices support SSH and NETCONF protocol, and the interface variables are unique per device. In which directory are the YAML files including variables hosted to automate the task with the netconf_config module?

comments.content: IT asked for directory for YML files for ansible not directory for host files.. A is correct
Correct, The YAML files including variables for the netconf_config module would be hosted in the host_vars directory.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
this should be B, unique per host, so in host vars

Selected Answer: B
I think it's B too:
"We document adding variables in the main inventory file for simplicity. However, storing variables in separate host and group variable files is a more robust approach to describing your system policy. Setting variables in the main inventory file is only a shorthand. See Organizing host and group variables for guidelines on storing variable values in individual files in the ‘host_vars’ directory"
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/inventory_guide/intro_inventory.html

choices.B: XML provides more human readability than JSON.
choices.A: XML provides more support for mapping data structures into host languages than JSON.
choices.D: JSON natively supports arrays and XML does not natively support arrays.
choices.C: JSON provides less support for data types than XML.

questions.question_text: How do XML and JSON compare regarding functionality?

discussion.content: D is correct. XML does not support arrays but JSON does.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct because of keyword "natively"

Selected Answer: D
B is not correct.
"As a markup language, XML is more complex and requires a tag structure.

In contrast, JSON is a data format that extends from JavaScript. It does not use tags, which makes it more compact and easier to read for humans."
https://aws.amazon.com/compare/the-difference-between-json-xml/

Selected Answer: D
Natively is the key

D seems to be correct,
note that it says "natively"

I'm not sure about B
since JSON is more readable than XML, well this is subjective if the person is used to XML

Selected Answer: B
In XML, arrays can be represented using repeating elements with the same name

Selected Answer: B
Option A is incorrect. Both XML and JSON support mapping data structures into host languages, although the specific mechanisms for doing so may differ.
Option C is incorrect. Both XML and JSON support a variety of data types, including strings, numbers, and Booleans.
Option D is incorrect. Both XML and JSON support arrays, although the syntax for representing arrays is different in the two formats. In XML, arrays can be represented using repeating elements with the same name, while in JSON, arrays are represented using square brackets.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct.

questions.question_text: Which standard supported by Cisco IOS XE and Cisco NX-OS is used for automating the configuration of multiple devices across a network?

A developer has addressed a bug that was found in the production code of an application. A separate file named ‘bug427896191v_fix” has been created with the changes to the code. Which Git command must be used to incorporate the bug fix into the production code?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
D. git bisert command doesn't exist
B. git cat-file is something about type and seems no related to the question.
A. git rebase seems to be related with merging different branches and here doesn't say nothing about different branches
I think the correct answer is C:
"git merge-file incorporates all changes that lead from the <base-file> to <other-file> into <current-file>. The result ordinarily goes into <current-file>. git merge-file is useful for combining separate changes to an original. Suppose <base-file> is the original, and both <current-file> and <other-file> are modifications of <base-file>, then git merge-file combines both changes."
For more details check here:
https://git-scm.com/docs/git-merge-file

Any other opinions?

choices.A: Changes are made after the code is submitted to source control.
choices.B: It must not prevent code from getting into production as quickly as possible.
choices.D: A technical lead must sign off on the review.

questions.question_text: What is a principle of a code review process?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I would pick C

Answer C:

Code review really has two purposes:

Improving the code. Finding bugs, anticipating possible bugs, checking the clarity of the code, and checking for consistency with the project’s style standards.'
Improving the programmer. Code review is an important way that programmers learn and teach each other, about new language features, changes in the design of the project or its coding standards, and new techniques. In open source projects, particularly, much conversation happens in the context of code reviews.

Selected Answer: A
branch -> develop -> commit -> pull request -> code review -> merge or comment.
I think "A" is answer.

Selected Answer: C
I think C
